title: Can music be copyrighted in a video even if you give the artist credit? - Quora

response.answer_text: All music is copyrighted (under copyright protection) from the moment of creation until a period of time proscribed by applicable law. For example, in the United States music created after January 1, 1978 have copyright protection for the life of the author plus an additional 70 years. For works created earlier or as a work-for-hire, copyright protection may last for more or less time. If you use such music without the copyright holder’s permission in a video, you risk receiving a copyright strike. Crediting the copyright holder is not the same as getting permission to use it. That merely informs viewers whose rights you are infringing by not getting permission to use their music.

You cannot use someone else's content without permission. Doing so is illegal copyright infringement. Sampling isn't legal so how could you get away with using the whole song? You need permission. And the recording artist can refuse to give it unless you pay them.

Copyright is a federal law and videos are usually copyrighted. For works created after Jan. 1, 1978, Copyrights last a lifetime plus 70 years. If the work is anonymous, It would last 95 years shorter of publication and 120 years from creation. For more info about copyright laws see Videomaker.com.

Since 1961, the performers who recorded a piece of music own the rights to that recording. If you want to use a recording of Vivaldi’s Gloria, you have to get permission from the recording artists and probably pay for the rights to use the recording. There are no free recordings these days.

Yes. The artist(s) will always have copyrights to their music unless they agree to a work for hire arrangement. Meaning the artists makes a product for a project and the owner of the project owns all rights. When you give an artist credit for their work it helps their portfolio and makes you look good for helping that artist(s). It's a win/win situation for both sides.
Yes, crediting an artist does not change the fact that you are violating copyright. In fact, the artist may not even be the entity you have to license from, it is more likely the record company.

The person who created the music owns the copyright not you, unless you sign a contract where they sell/give you the rights. Make sure you have a specific agreement that their music is licensed to you for use in your video.
